I have been thinking about this a lot lately since we have some messy
threading code in our gui.  Our main problems are locking down objects
while state transitions are occuring.  We wrote some pretty basic thread
tools based on ones in various books and then wrote unit tests for them.
It turns out that the unit tests were extremely tricky but I haven't found
an easier way to test mulithreaded behavior.

Below I have attached a read/write lock implementation and the accompanying
unit test.  The unit test uses a conditional event and so I have included
that also.  I have stripped out all the code and just left the signatures
and comments from the ReadWriteLock and ConditionalEvent since I don't
think my employer wants me publishing its code, but I have left the entire
test intact.

I could not get to javaranch so I could not get to your original post, but
if you want to send some code (even if it is privately), I would be willing
to take a look.

-Phil

I've asked this question at javaranch.com, so I'll just provide an
brief description here and point to the original question for anyone
who wants to give it a shot (just reply on this list though).

I'm writing the beginnings of a multithreaded server, and I had to
insert a lot of calls to Thread.sleep() in my unit testing code for
it to pass.  Is there some good way to test multithreaded code that
doesn't invole just waiting a few milliseconds and hoping that a task
finished?  I imagine that a better solution might involve calls to
join() but tie the unit test closely to the particular implementation.

Anyway, here's the original question with my current, unsatisfactory
test (although it doesn't have much of the code being tested - I
didn't want to clutter the post.  I should add some.):
